tips.description: Download compressed data and uncompress with CURL
contents: Add `--compressed` option to curl to auto decompress data after download.
e.g. curl --compressed https://api.stackexchange.com/2.2/sites

tips.description: tempfile in Python
contents: Use tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile() callable to have a temporary file with a visible name
By default, file is opened in binary mode and is deleted on closing
Use "w+" to open in text mode.
Also works with context manager.
>>> with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile() as fp:
...     fp.write(b'Hello world!')
...     fp.seek(0)
...     fp.read()
b'Hello world!'

tips.description: Python: Get home directory
contents: Class method pathlib.Path.home() returns a new path object
representing user home directory (similar to os.path.expanduser("~")
Path object also supports / operator, so Path.home()/subdir/file is also possible

tips.description: Find which shell I am in
contents: Run "echo $SHELL"
root@88a325681e8c:/# echo $SHELL
/bin/bash

tips.description: Find system information from command line
contents: uname, uname -a
root@88a325681e8c:/# uname -a
Linux 88a325681e8c 4.9.184-linuxkit #1 SMP Tue Jul 2 22:58:16 UTC 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

tips.description: Find disk usage of directory and files with "du"
contents: du -a - display an entry for each file in the directory
du -c - display a grand total
du -h - display info in human readable form (take optional unit suffixes (-m for MB, -g for GB))
du -d <depth> - stop at given depth level

tips.description: Access last executed command in shell
contents: Use "!!" to access the last ran command

tips.description: Get status of last command/process
contents: $? - return the status of the last command ran in shell

tips.description: Access arguments from last command
contents: !^ - First argument
!$ - Last argument
!* - All arguments

tips.description: Colorize ls output
contents: ls --color=always (on most Linux)
ls -G (on macOS)

tips.description: List files with their disk usage
contents: $ ls -lash
Shows a **long** listing of **all** files along with their
**actual file size in number of blocks** (typically 512 bytes) and
file size in **human readable** form (e.g B for bytes, K for kilobytes, G for gigabytes etc)

tips.description: Supress newline character in shell
contents: `echo -n` - skips the trailing newline character
Note: some shells do not support -n option.
For portability, use printf instead.

tips.description: Sort lines in shell
contents: sort - command to sort lines of text or binary data from standard input or a file descriptor.
Default order: lexicographic
-k <column number> - sort by a specific key
-n - sort numerically
-s - keep the sorting order stable

tips.description: Generate sequence of numbers
contents: seq - Generate sequence of numbers
starts from 1 and increments 1 by default
$ seq 4 // generate 1 to 4
$ seq 10 2 20 // generate 10 to 20, increment by 2

tips.description: Find system calls used by a program
contents: strace <program>

tips.description: Find disk usage of files and directories
contents: du - find disk usage of a directory and its files
-a - display an entry for each file in the directory
-c - display a grand total
-h - display info in human readable form (take optional unit suffixes: -m for MB, -g for GB)
-d <depth> - stop at given depth level

tips.description: Where man pages are stored?
contents: Pages are searched first in the path given by option `-M` if specified.
If `-M` is not specified, then the path specified in `MANPATH` is looked up.
If neither `-M` nor `MANPATH` is specified, then the path to man pages is inferred from the config file.
In general, the default set of man pages live in `/usr/share/man/`
Applications can install in other paths too and update the `MANPATH` accordingly.
The location of the config file can differ based on the distribution.
/private/etc/man.conf - in macOS Mojave
/etc/man.config - in many linux distributions

tips.description: Convert epoch seconds into date
contents: % date -r <seconds> # macOS
$ date -d @<seconds> # on most linux
$ date +%s # display current time in epoch seconds

tips.description: Toggle reader mode in Safari
contents: `Cmd + Shift + R` - toggles reader mode on supported sites

tips.description: Find files modified in last x minutes or x days
contents: `$ find . -mmin -60` - find files modified in the last 60 minutes in current directory
`$ find . -mtime -2` - find files modified in the last 48 hours in current directory

tips.description: Find files accessed in last x minutes or x days
contents: `$ find . -amin -60` - find files modified in the last 60 minutes in current directory
`$ find . -atime -2` - find files modified in the last 48 hours in current directory

tips.description: sshpass - specify password for ssh/scp login non-interactively
contents: `sshpass -p <password> ssh user@host "command to run"` - Use the specified password to connect using ssh
`sshpass -p <password> scp <source> <destination>` - Use the specified password to connect using scp
`SSHPASS=password sshpass -e ssh user@host command` - Take the password from the environment variable SSHPASS

tips.description: scp - some helpful options (pqr)
contents: `-p` - Preserve modification times, access times, and modes
`-q` - Quiet mode: disables the progress meter as well as warning and diagnostic messages from ssh
`-r` - Recursively copy entire directories

tips.description: ssh options - Ignore host key checking
contents: `-o StrictHostKeyChecking=no` - automatically add new host keys to users known hosts file. Often not needed in controlled environments
`-o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null` - Use /dev/null instead of the default file (~/.ssh/known_hosts)
Set `StrictHostKeyChecking no` in .ssh/config under `Host <hostname>` to apply this to per hosts

tips.description: bash - a quick note on arrays
contents: arr=() # Create empty array
arr+=(5) # Append a number to array
arr+=(xyz) # Append a text to array; arrays can have numbers and strings
${arr[@]} # Get all items from the array
${!arr[@]} # Get all indices of the array. Index starts at 0
${arr[3]} # Get the fourth item from the array
${arr} # Get first item from the array. Equivalent to ${arr[0]}
${arr[@]:i:n} # Get n elements starting at index i
arr=( $(cmd) ) # Save output of a command into an array
# Sample for loop
for item in ${arr[@]};do
echo $item
done

tips.description: vim - show relative and absolute file path
contents: Ctrl+G - shows the relative path of the current file
{n}Ctrl+G - shows the relative path of the nth file in the buffer
1Ctrl+G - shows the absolute path of the current file

tips.description: vim - set/toggle option
contents: :set <option> - switches on a toggle option
:set <option>! - toggles the option
:set <option>? - shows the value of option
e.g :set nu - turns on the line number, :set nonumber - turns off the line number
:set nu! toggles the line number on or off,

tips.description: bash: read inputs
contents: $ read var # gets the input from the user and assings to the variable "var"
$ read -p "Prompt" var # shows the prompt message
$ read -ps "Prompt" var # shows the prompt message, but keeps the input hidden.
E.g.
$ read -p "Select: " choice
Select: 1
$ echo $choice
